5.text:
Colin Powel:
Thank you very much, Patrick, for your testimony,

8.text:
I should say. And I mean testimony in the
right way, not Congressional way. Testimony.

14.text:
Colin Powel:
It's a great pleasure to have you all here

16.text:
this morning. And Patrick in his remarks told
you what America's Promise is all about. Why

22.text:
we started it some 13 years ago. All of our
living presidents came together with Nancy

27.text:
Reagan representing President Reagan and said
to the nation in a nation where all of our

33.text:
wealth with, all that we have, how can it
be that we have millions of children who wonder

38.text:
if the American dream is there for them. Millions
of children who wonder if they can get a quality

43.text:
education, where they are going in the future.
And we committed ourselves at that point to

47.text:
get into the lives of these youngsters who
are wondering about their future and we have

53.text:
been very successful over the last 13 years.
We have expanded programs through the work

58.text:
of Boys and Girls Clubs of America, through
Salvation Army programs, through Youthbuild

63.text:
as you heard Patrick describe, and we're very
pleased with what we have accomplished. And

68.text:
the promises that we made to ourselves and
to the young people of America back then were

72.text:
very simple: Every young person should have
responsible caring adults in their lives.

77.text:
You heard Patrick talk about the responsible
caring adults that saved him and brought him

81.text:
back online. Second, we ought to have safe
places in which our children can learn and

86.text:
to grow, whether it's an after school program,
a boys and girls club, whatever it is, in

90.text:
Patrick's case it was Youthbuild. Third, we
ought to make sure that every child has health

95.text:
care and a healthy start in life. And fourth,
an education that is useable of the kind that

102.text:
Patrick is getting. And fifth, every youngster
early in life should be taught to give back

107.text:
to serve the community as it served you. As
you heard Patrick say he is now trying to

112.text:
serve his community by speaking and by participating
in service projects. There was one thing wrong

118.text:
with what Patrick said. One thing very wrong.
He had already dropped out and he had to be

125.text:
captured and brought back online. That's not
good enough any more. We have got to catch

130.text:
our kids long before they drop out. The whole
purpose of America's Promise, the reason we

135.text:
are here this morning is to focus on a simple
problem that too many of our youngsters are

140.text:
dropping out. They drop out when they get
to high school but they start dropping out

144.text:
in the second, third and fourth grade. They
drop out when they realize they are behind

148.text:
some other youngster because in their home
environment nobody read to them. Nobody taught

153.text:
them their numbers, nobody taught them their
colors. They showed up in school understanding

157.text:
that they might be a little behind within
the first week of school when they see other

161.text:
kids who have had that family and community
embrace. Our kids start dropping out when

166.text:
they realize that they are falling behind
and when they're falling behind then they

170.text:
start acting like they are falling behind. As
one teacher once said to me here in a Washington,

174.text:
D.C. school, kids all start the same way,
with lights in their eyes flashing, but about

181.text:
the age of eight or nine that light starts
to go out unless it's reinforced. And so America's

188.text:
Promise has been focusing on this with all
of the other partners that we work on especially

192.text:
working with the Department of Education and
so many other wonderful nonprofit organizations

197.text:
throughout our country. But there is more
that has to be done. We have been scaling

201.text:
up America's Promise activities from the five
promises to dropout summits around the country

208.text:
and from dropout summits to best communities
in America so we can focus on those who are

212.text:
doing a good job. And now today we take it
up to another level, Grad Nation. Make this

218.text:
a nation of graduates, not a nation of dropouts.
So many of our youngsters are doing very well.

222.text:
We've got the greatest universities. Wonderful
high school kids are going into those universities.

227.text:
But the reality is a third of all of our students
are not finishing high school and 50 percent

233.text:
of our minority kids are not finishing high
school. And that's what we are focusing on

236.text:
now. That's what we'll be focusing on this
morning. I want to ask all of you to continue

242.text:
to do your part in this noble effort that
we're involved in. We want to make sure that

247.text:
in the years ahead we can look back on this
event as one of the changing events, one of

252.text:
the transformational events in our education
and youth programs by starting to put us on

257.text:
a path to being a grad nation, a nation of
graduates. We don't do it just because it's

262.text:
the moral thing to do, which it is, we do
it for our own economic future and our own

267.text:
future security. We, 300 million Americans
in a world of 6.8 billion people, cannot afford

274.text:
to lose a single youngster. We owe it to them.
We owe it to ourselves. And I thank you for

280.text:
your support. And now it is my great pleasure
and honor to introduce the chair person of

286.text:
America's Promise. I used to be the chair
of America's Promise. She is now the chair

291.text:
of America's Promise and doing a
fabulous job, my wife Alma Powell.

305.text:
Alma Powell:
Thank you, Colin.
Thank you, Colin. It

308.text:
is really a great pleasure for me to be here
this morning and I am very excited about our

314.text:
announcement today. When people ask me what
America's promise means to me I think about

321.text:
all of the young people in the world and what
they need to succeed. I think about my own

327.text:
children. We have had the sheer joy of raising
three young people to adulthood who now in

333.text:
their own way are giving back to their communities.
But to whom much is given, much is expected.

342.text:
And so our attention and our efforts turn to
the young people of America. Over the past

350.text:
two years since we announced the dropout prevention
summits, our alliance has convened dropout

357.text:
prevention summits in every state and 55 cities
bringing together all sectors of the community

365.text:
to address this urgent problem. Later this
year we will issue a report on the progress

371.text:
that was made since our collaborative dropout
prevention work began. But now it's time to

378.text:
turn awareness into sustained concerted action.
I'm excited to announce to you today the next

386.text:
phase of our work. We are undertaking a ten-year
campaign to mobilize this nation to reverse

392.text:
the dropout crisis and ensure that our children
are prepared for college and the workforce.

400.text:
This campaign will be called Grad Nation.
Just 12 percent of our high schools account

409.text:
for over half of all dropouts. So Grad Nation
will focus on these 2,000 lowest performing

418.text:
schools and their neighborhoods. Through our
national alliance partners and their networks

424.text:
of local affiliates we are harnessing the
power of community partnerships in places

429.text:
where the need and the potential impact will
be the greatest. Especially in these 2,000

436.text:
neighborhoods. We will bring the power of
the five promises into the lives of more children

443.text:
in ways that change the odds and change futures.
This effort would not be possible without

451.text:
the generosity of our partners and the support
of the over 300 alliance partners that we

458.text:
have around the country. I want to specifically
thank Brian Gallagher and recognize him and

466.text:
United Way. Brian Gallagher, President and
CEO of United Way. As a member of our alliance's

474.text:
board of directors and trustees, Brian has
helped to shape our work and the entire United

480.text:
Way network is pursuing our shared goals.
In these partners and so many others we see

488.text:
leaders who recognize that all of us must
be part of the solution. And we have made

495.text:
a goal of enlisting 100 new business partners
to join the Grad Nation campaign. What we

505.text:
have to understand in this effort and as we
go forward and what I try to do was I raise

510.text:
awareness of the problem is we have to understand
that there is no "they" in facing this problem

517.text:
and working to alleviate it; there is just
us. Just us. And so we have to think of that,

527.text:
whether it's keeping young people in school,
bringing them back to school, or making sure

532.text:
that they graduate with the skills for college
and a career. There is almost no limit to

539.text:
how organizations can help. For example, City
Year has launched an initiative that focuses

546.text:
on at-risk young people falling off the track
for graduation. Citizen Schools is engaging

552.text:
volunteers and after school education programs
for middle schoolers. The First Tee is expanding

559.text:
its national schools program for students
in grades K through 5. And 4H is reaching

565.text:
5 million young people each year with learning
experiences in science, engineering and technology

572.text:
projects. But we all know that there are so
many things that individuals can do and each

578.text:
one of us has to ask every day what's my part
in this. What can I do. Well, for starters

586.text:
you become more involved in the education
of your own children and those that are their

591.text:
companions. Help connect them and others with
the resources that they need for success.

596.text:
Tutor students after school. Be a mentor.
Did you know that students who meet regularly

605.text:
with a mentor are 50 percent less likely to
skip school? That caring adult who is always

611.text:
looking for them and welcomes them with a
smile or shoulder to lean on when they have

616.text:
a problem. It doesn't take a lot of effort
to do that. Just the will. It can be a part

624.text:
of a career exploration program. This is a
proven way to keep students engaged and motivated.

631.text:
We can donate books to children. But more
importantly, read to children. There are so

638.text:
many opportunities to do that around us every
day. Urge your school district to participate

645.text:
in our Gallop Student Poll which measures
some of the most reliable indicators of whether

651.text:
students are ready for the future. School
districts and communities across the country

656.text:
are already using this poll data to determine
new ways to help students succeed. In all

663.text:
of these ways and more we need individuals
and organizations to be involved. We, with

672.text:
your help, have to mobilize all Americans.
I am very encouraged because often I turn

680.text:
on the radio and I hear these discussions.
Just the other day on NPR they were holding

685.text:
a town meeting at a school here in Washington
where parents and educators had come together

690.text:
to talk about what it is these statistics
mean and what we need to do to change that.

696.text:
And that's good. We're glad that we have people
talking about it but now we want them to act

702.text:
on it. Our campaign is more like a marathon
than a sprint. We're not going to become a

712.text:
grad nation overnight. But working together
we will be a grad nation and we will secure

718.text:
our future as a great nation. Since taking
office just over a year ago President Obama

725.text:
has made the education of our young people
a key priority even amid all of the urgent

731.text:
priorities that he has. He and Secretary Duncan
know and fully understand the challenges that

740.text:
we face. They know that this must be our goal.
This is our goal here at America's Promise.

749.text:
This is what we are dedicated to. And we want
everyone to understand and accept the role

755.text:
that all of us must play in this crucial issue.
And I am happy that our President embraces

761.text:
this need and is committed to making a difference.
Ladies and gentlemen, this morning I have

768.text:
the great honor to introduce to you
the President of the United States.

794.text:
President Obama:
Thank you. Thank you so much. Thank you very

799.text:
much. Thank you. Everybody please have a seat.
Let me begin by acknowledging some of the

807.text:
extraordinary people who are working on this
extraordinary project. First of all, I want

816.text:
everybody to know, in case you haven't already
met him, somebody who is working tirelessly

820.text:
on behalf of the young people of America,
my Secretary of Education, Arne Duncan.

833.text:
I want to acknowledge Marguerite Kondracke,
the CEO of America's Promise, who is going

839.text:
to be implementing so much of the terrific
work that's been discussed today. Marguerite

848.text:
I want to thank Tom Donohue for your hospitality
in this extraordinary venue; thank you very

854.text:
much and thanks for the Chamber's support
for this terrific effort. I want to acknowledge

860.text:
Margaret Spellings, Arne's predecessor, who
helped to lead a lot of the improvement that's

867.text:
been taking place and we're building on. And
obviously I want to thank the Powells --

873.text:
and I will start with the more important Powell,
Alma. (Laughter.) I want to say a word about

882.text:
the remarkable woman who introduced me, a
champion of children, a dedicated public servant

887.text:
and the recipient of numerous awards. And
Alma has poured herself into America's Promise

895.text:
Alliance, helping make it the largest partnership
of its kind to improve education and help

900.text:
children in this country. And perhaps that's
not surprising, because being an educator

907.text:
seems to run in the family, as I understand.
Even though one of her mother's parents was

912.text:
born into slavery and the other, just after
abolition, both went to college, became teachers,

920.text:
four of their children followed them into
the education profession. So her family has

925.text:
educated and enriched generations of Americans
-- and our nation is better off because for

931.text:
it. And so we are very grateful to you for
your extraordinary leadership. Thank you.

943.text:
There's not much we can say about the man
that Alma succeeds as chair of the Alliance

949.text:
that most people don't already know, anyway.
I will say that I'm grateful for his friendship,

955.text:
for his counsel, and like so many Americans,
I continue to be inspired by his leadership

960.text:
and by his life's story. It's a story of a
son of Jamaican garment workers, a student

965.text:
from the South Bronx, like me wasn't always
at his best in high school, but who went to

973.text:
City College of New York thanks to the support
of his family and his friends and his community.

978.text:
It's a story of a ROTC cadet who went on to
distinguish himself first in Vietnam, then

985.text:
in the Pentagon, in the White House, and in
the State Department; and who, after spending

990.text:
a lifetime fighting of behalf of America,
has now taken up the fight for America's children.

997.text:
So the leadership of Colin and Alma are --
that they are showing by spearheading the

1005.text:
Grad Nation Campaign to end America's dropout
crisis is just the latest chapter in their

1010.text:
service to this nation. And so I want to publicly
commend them and thank them for their extraordinary

1025.text:
One last person I want to make mention of,
because I think it bears on the extraordinary

1029.text:
public-private partnership that's taking place
here, we have the CEO of the Corporation for

1034.text:
National Community Service, Patrick Corvington,
who is here. Where's Patrick? There he is

1043.text:
And so we are hoping to -- we're hoping to
make sure we get a whole bunch of volunteers

1047.text:
engaged in this effort. Now, it's fitting
that we're talking about education here at

1053.text:
the Chamber of Commerce. After all, for America
to compete and to win in the 21st century,

1060.text:
we know that we will need a highly educated
workforce that is second to none. And we know

1066.text:
that the success of every American will be
tied more closely than ever before to the

1071.text:
level of education that they achieve. The
jobs will go to the people with the knowledge

1078.text:
and the skills to do them -- it's that simple.
In this kind of knowledge economy, giving

1084.text:
up on your education and dropping out of school
means not only giving up on your future, but

1090.text:
it's also giving up on your family's future
and giving up on your country's future. And

1095.text:
yet, that's what too many of America's children
are doing today. Over 1 million students don't

1103.text:
finish high school each year -- nearly one
in three. Over half are African American and

1109.text:
Latino. The graduation gap in some places
between white students and classmates of color

1116.text:
is 40 or 50 percent. And in cities like Detroit
and Indianapolis and Baltimore, graduation

1123.text:
rates hover around 30, 40 percent -- roughly
half the national average. Now, it's true

1133.text:
that not long ago, you could drop out of high
school and reasonably expect to find a blue-collar

1139.text:
job that would pay the bills and help support
your family. That's just not the case anymore.

1145.text:
In recent years, a high school dropout has
made, on average, about $10,000 less per year

1152.text:
than a high school graduate. In fact, during
this recession, a high school dropout has

1158.text:
been more than three times as likely to be
out of work as someone with at least a college

1164.text:
degree. Graduating from high school is an
economic imperative. That might be the best

1172.text:
reason to get a diploma, but it's not the
only reason to get a high school diploma.

1179.text:
As Alma mentioned, high school dropouts are
more likely to be teen parents, more likely

1184.text:
to commit crime, more likely to rely on public
assistance, more likely to lead shattered

1190.text:
lives. What's more, they cost our economy
hundreds of billions of dollars over the course

1197.text:
of a lifetime in lower wages and higher public
expenses. So this is a problem we cannot afford

1205.text:
to accept and we cannot afford to ignore.
The stakes are too high -- for our children,

1211.text:
for our economy, and for our country. It's
time for all of us to come together -- parents,

1218.text:
students, principals and teachers, business
leaders and elected officials from across

1225.text:
the political spectrum -- to end America's
dropout crisis. This is a problem that I've

1232.text:
actually been fighting for years. Way back
when, when I was a community organizer in

1237.text:
Chicago, I saw what happened to a family or
to a school or to a community when a student

1243.text:
dropped out. So I helped work with local churches
in the region to -- and public school officials

1250.text:
to get state funding for dropout prevention
programs, and brought together African American

1256.text:
and Latino leaders to help set up after-school
programs -- because when we help keep kids

1262.text:
off the street, when we give them a productive
way to spend their time, then graduation rates

1267.text:
go up. So that's a commitment that I've carried
with me to the Oval Office. And today, I want

1273.text:
to announce steps my administration will take
to help end the dropout crisis in the African

1279.text:
American community, in the Latino community,
and in the larger American community. Because

1284.text:
we know that about 12 percent of America's
schools produce 50 percent of America's dropouts,

1291.text:
we're going to focus on helping states and school
districts turn around their 5,000 lowest-performing

1297.text:
schools in the next five years, and Arne will
be amplifying and providing details on how

1302.text:
we can do this. We'll not only challenge states
to identify high schools with graduation rates

1308.text:
below 60 percent, we're going to invest another
$900 million in strategies to get those graduation

1314.text:
rates up. Strategies like transforming schools
from top to bottom by bringing in a new principal,

1321.text:
and training teachers to use more effective
techniques in the classroom. Strategies like

1327.text:
closing a school for a time and reopening
it under new management, or even shutting

1332.text:
it down entirely and sending its students
to a better school. And strategies like replacing

1339.text:
a school's principal and at least half of
its staff. Now, replacing school staff should

1345.text:
only be done as a last resort. The public
servants who work in America's schools --

1350.text:
whether they're principals or teachers, or
counselors or coaches -- work long and hard

1354.text:
on behalf of our children and they deserve
our gratitude. Keep in mind I've got a sister

1357.text:
who's a teacher, my mother spent time teaching
-- one of the most important jobs that we

1364.text:
have in this country. We've got an obligation
as a country to give them the support they

1368.text:
need -- because when principals and teachers
succeed, then our children succeed. So if

1375.text:
a school is struggling, we have to work with
the principal and the teachers to find a solution.

1380.text:
We've got to give them a chance to make meaningful
improvements. But if a school continues to

1387.text:
fail its students year after year after year,
if it doesn't show signs of improvement, then

1393.text:
there's got to be a sense of accountability.
And that's what happened in Rhode Island last

1398.text:
week at a chronically troubled school, when
just 7 percent of 11th graders passed state

1403.text:
math tests -- 7 percent. When a school board
wasn't able to deliver change by other means,

1410.text:
they voted to lay off the faculty and the
staff. As my Education Secretary, Arne Duncan,

1416.text:
says, our kids get only one chance at an education,
and we need to get it right.

1423.text:
Of course, getting it right requires more
than just transforming our lowest performing

1430.text:
schools. It requires giving students who are
behind in school a chance to catch up and

1436.text:
a path to a diploma. It requires focusing
on students, from middle school through high

1442.text:
school, who face factors at home, in the neighborhood,
or in school that put them at risk of dropping

1447.text:
out. And it requires replicating innovative
ideas that make class feel engaging and relevant

1453.text:
-- because most high school dropouts in a
recent study said the reason they dropped

1457.text:
out was that they weren't interested in class
and they weren't motivated to do their work.

1463.text:
So that's why we'll build on the efforts of
places like Communities in Schools that make

1468.text:
sure kids who are at risk of dropping out
have one-on-one support. That's why we'll

1474.text:
follow the example of places like the Met
Center in Rhode Island that give students

1479.text:
that individual attention, while also preparing
them through real-world, hands-on training

1486.text:
the possibility of succeeding in a career.
And that's why we'll invest in accelerated

1492.text:
instruction in reading and math to help students
who've fallen behind make up credits and ultimately

1498.text:
graduate on time. It's also why we'll foster
better alternative high schools and transfer

1505.text:
schools, where students who have dropped out
and who are at risk of dropping out, can return

1510.text:
to the classroom and earn their diploma. That's
how we can curb dropout rates and boost graduating

1518.text:
rates. I have to point out, in the 21st century,
high schools shouldn't just make sure students

1524.text:
graduate -- they should make sure students
graduate ready for college, ready for a career,

1530.text:
and ready for life. And that's why we'll foster
what are called early college high schools

1538.text:
that allow students to earn a high school
diploma and an associate's degree or college

1542.text:
credit at the same time. We want to learn
from successful charter schools where students

1549.text:
can take advanced and college-level courses.
So government has a responsibility. Government

1559.text:
can help educate students to succeed in college
and a career. Government can help provide

1566.text:
the resources to engage dropouts and those
at risk of dropping out. And when necessary,

1574.text:
government has to be critically involved in
turning around lowest performing schools.

1579.text:
And nobody has been more passionate about
this than Arne Duncan. But as I've said before,

1587.text:
education is not and cannot be the task of
government alone. It's going to take nonprofits

1594.text:
and businesses doing their part through alliances
like America's Promise. It will take parents

1601.text:
getting involved in their children's education,
consistently -- going to parent-teacher conferences,

1608.text:
helping their children with their homework.
I have to point out I just went to my daughter's

1614.text:
parent-teachers' conference last week.
She's doing very well, by the way.

1624.text:
It will take students, as well, showing up to
school on time and paying attention to classes

1629.text:
and staying out of trouble. They're not let
off the hook. Education isn't a passive activity;

1634.text:
it's an active one. So educating America's
sons and daughters is a task for all Americans.

1642.text:
And that's what this alliance, that's what
this effort is all about -- making sure that

1647.text:
none of us think that it's somebody else's
job, but rather we all accept our role to

1654.text:
play in making sure that we have the best-educated
citizenry in the world. That's what has made

1664.text:
the 20th century the American century; that's
what will make the 21st century the American

1670.text:
century. Now, there's an old story that Colin
has told about a man named George Ellis, who

1677.text:
lived about a hundred years ago. And George
Ellis was a janitor. His job was to clean

1682.text:
up after the artist Daniel Chester French.
Some of you may have heard of French -- he's

1689.text:
the one who carved the figure of Abraham Lincoln
for the Lincoln Memorial. So day after day,

1695.text:
week after week, month after month, Ellis
went about his job, barely uttering a word

1701.text:
to Mr. French, other than say the occasional
"hello" or "goodbye." And then one day, just

1707.text:
when French had nearly completed his masterpiece,
Ellis spoke up. He said, "Mr. French, I have

1712.text:
a question for you." So the artist said, "What
is it?" "Well, what I want to ask is how you

1718.text:
knew all along that Mr. Lincoln was sitting
inside that block of marble." And as Colin

1724.text:
pointed out, that wasn't a silly question.
Because sometimes in this country and in our

1732.text:
lives, we see blocks of marble and some people
can see what's inside and some people can't.

1738.text:
It was a question profound -- it was a profound
question about how we recognize the potential

1745.text:
within each of us, and chisel away at what's
keeping it locked inside. I'm absolutely confident

1752.text:
that because of the work of Colin and Alma
Powell, because of the work that Grad Nation

1759.text:
campaign is going to be doing and America's
Promise Alliance is going to be doing, because

1762.text:
of the work that we're doing across this nation
to give our children the best education the

1766.text:
world has to offer, from cradle to classroom,
from college through career, that we are chiseling
